metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Responses to the conflict between optimal rate and temperature considerations in producing equilibrium reaction products, with reference to the green chemistry principles of catalysis and designing for energy efficiency

rate_yield_conflict.name: Rate vs Yield Conflict
rate_yield_conflict.formula: High T â†’ fast rate but may reduce yield for exothermic reactions
rate_yield_conflict.correct: For exothermic reactions, high temperatures increase reaction rate but shift equilibrium toward reactants, reducing yield. A compromise must be found.

high temperatures always increase both r.error: Temperature affects rate and yield differently.
high temperatures always increase both r.fix: High T increases rate for ALL reactions, but only increases yield for ENDOTHERMIC reactions.
high temperatures always increase both r.action: Check Î”H sign. Exothermic (Î”H < 0): high T = fast but low yield.

rate and yield are the same thing.error: Rate and yield are different concepts.
rate and yield are the same thing.fix: Rate = how fast products form. Yield = how much product at equilibrium.
rate and yield are the same thing.action: Fast reaction can still have low equilibrium yield, and vice versa.

there is no conflict between rate and yi.error: For exothermic reactions, there is a direct conflict.
there is no conflict between rate and yi.fix: Conditions that increase rate (high T) can decrease yield for exothermic reactions.
there is no conflict between rate and yi.action: The Haber process is a classic example of this conflict.

low temperatures always give the best ou.error: Low T may favour yield but reaction becomes too slow.
low temperatures always give the best ou.fix: Low T for exothermic reactions increases yield but drastically slows the rate.
low temperatures always give the best ou.action: Industrial processes need reasonable rates AND acceptable yields.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how temperature affects rate and equilibrium differently.
persistent.action: Make a table comparing temperature effects on rate vs yield for exothermic and endothermic reactions.

temperature_effect_rate.name: Temperature Effect on Rate
temperature_effect_rate.correct: Increasing temperature ALWAYS increases reaction rate by increasing collision frequency and the proportion of particles with energy exceeding activation energy.

decreases rate.error: Reversed. Higher temperature means faster reactions.
decreases rate.fix: More kinetic energy â†’ more frequent collisions â†’ more successful collisions â†’ faster rate.
decreases rate.action: Think: does food cook faster in a hot oven or cold fridge?

only increases rate for endothermic reac.error: Temperature increases rate for ALL reactions, not just endothermic ones.
only increases rate for endothermic reac.fix: Rate depends on collision theory. Equilibrium position depends on Le Chatelier's principle. Different concepts.
only increases rate for endothermic reac.action: Separate rate (kinetics) from equilibrium (thermodynamics) in your thinking.

has no effect on rate.error: Temperature is one of the most significant factors affecting reaction rate.
has no effect on rate.fix: Higher T increases both collision frequency and proportion of successful collisions.
has no effect on rate.action: Review collision theory and the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution.

only increases rate when a catalyst is p.error: Temperature affects rate independently of catalysts.
only increases rate when a catalyst is p.fix: Temperature and catalysts both increase rate, but by different mechanisms.
only increases rate when a catalyst is p.action: T increases particle energy. Catalyst provides alternative pathway. Both work independently.

persistent.gap: You are confusing temperature's effect on rate with its effect on equilibrium.
persistent.action: Study collision theory separately from Le Chatelier's principle.

temperature_effect_equilibrium_exothermi.name: Temperature Effect on Exothermic Equilibrium
temperature_effect_equilibrium_exothermi.formula: Exothermic: â†‘T â†’ equilibrium shifts left (â†“yield)
temperature_effect_equilibrium_exothermi.correct: For exothermic reactions (Î”H < 0), increasing temperature shifts equilibrium toward reactants, decreasing product yield.

shifts equilibrium toward products.fix: Heat is a product in exothermic reactions. Adding heat (â†‘T) favours the reverse reaction.
shifts equilibrium toward products.action: Write heat on the products side: A + B â†’ C + heat. Adding heat shifts left.

has no effect on equilibrium position.error: Temperature changes ALWAYS shift equilibrium position.
has no effect on equilibrium position.fix: Temperature is the only factor that changes both equilibrium position AND the value of K.
has no effect on equilibrium position.action: Unlike adding reactants or changing pressure, temperature actually changes K.

only affects rate, not equilibrium.error: Temperature affects both rate and equilibrium, but differently.
only affects rate, not equilibrium.fix: Rate always increases with T. Equilibrium shift depends on whether reaction is exo- or endothermic.
only affects rate, not equilibrium.action: This is exactly why there is a conflict to optimise.

shifts equilibrium but does not change K.error: Temperature is the one factor that DOES change K.
shifts equilibrium but does not change K.fix: For exothermic reactions, increasing T decreases K. For endothermic, increasing T increases K.
shifts equilibrium but does not change K.action: K is temperature-dependent. This is a key difference from concentration/pressure changes.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how Le Chatelier's principle applies to temperature changes.
persistent.action: Practice writing heat as a product (exo) or reactant (endo), then apply Le Chatelier's principle.

compromise_conditions.name: Compromise Conditions
compromise_conditions.formula: Moderate T + catalyst = optimal rate and yield
compromise_conditions.correct: Industrial processes use moderate temperatures (not too high, not too low) combined with catalysts to achieve acceptable rates without sacrificing too much yield.

use the highest possible temperature.error: Too high a temperature sacrifices yield for exothermic reactions.
use the highest possible temperature.fix: Moderate temperature balances reasonable rate with acceptable yield.
use the highest possible temperature.action: The Haber process uses 400-500Â°C, not 1000Â°C, despite faster rates at higher T.

use the lowest possible temperature.error: Too low a temperature makes the reaction impractically slow.
use the lowest possible temperature.fix: Even if yield is high, a reaction that takes years is not economically viable.
use the lowest possible temperature.action: Consider: 99% yield in 10 years vs 30% yield in 10 minutes. Which is more practical?

avoid using catalysts.error: Catalysts are essential for achieving good rates at lower temperatures.
avoid using catalysts.fix: Catalysts increase rate without affecting equilibrium position, solving the rate-yield conflict.
avoid using catalysts.action: Catalysts are the key to green chemistry principle of energy efficiency.

only consider yield, not rate.error: Both rate and yield must be optimised for industrial viability.
only consider yield, not rate.fix: A compromise considers economic factors: cost of heating, time to produce, amount produced.
only consider yield, not rate.action: Industrial chemistry balances chemistry with economics.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why compromise conditions are necessary in industrial chemistry.
persistent.action: Research the actual conditions used in the Haber process and why each was chosen.

catalyst_role.name: Catalyst Role in Equilibrium
catalyst_role.formula: Catalyst: â†‘rate, no change to K or equilibrium position
catalyst_role.correct: Catalysts increase the rate of both forward and reverse reactions equally. They help reach equilibrium faster but do not change the equilibrium position or yield.

increases yield.error: Catalysts do not change equilibrium position or yield.
increases yield.fix: Catalysts speed up reaching equilibrium but do not shift where equilibrium lies.
increases yield.action: Same destination, faster journey. The endpoint (equilibrium) is unchanged.

only speeds up forward reaction.error: Catalysts speed up both forward AND reverse reactions equally.
only speeds up forward reaction.fix: The catalyst provides a lower activation energy pathway for BOTH directions.
only speeds up forward reaction.action: If only forward was faster, equilibrium would shift. It does not, so both must increase equally.

changes the value of K.error: K depends only on temperature, not on catalysts.
changes the value of K.fix: Catalysts affect rate (kinetics) not equilibrium constant (thermodynamics).
changes the value of K.action: K is calculated from equilibrium concentrations. Catalyst does not change these.

allows reactions to occur that otherwise.error: Catalysts speed up reactions that would happen anyway, just slowly.
allows reactions to occur that otherwise.fix: Without catalyst, equilibrium is still reached eventually. Catalyst just gets there faster.
allows reactions to occur that otherwise.action: The reaction is thermodynamically possible; catalyst addresses kinetic barrier.

persistent.gap: You confuse what catalysts can and cannot change.
persistent.action: Memorise: Catalysts change RATE only. They do NOT change K, equilibrium position, or yield.

green_chemistry_catalysis.name: Green Chemistry Principle: Catalysis
green_chemistry_catalysis.formula: Principle 9: Use catalysts to reduce energy and waste
green_chemistry_catalysis.correct: The green chemistry principle of catalysis states that catalytic reagents are superior to stoichiometric reagents. Catalysts allow reactions at lower temperatures, reducing energy consumption.

catalysis is principle 1.error: Catalysis is principle 9 of the 12 green chemistry principles.
catalysis is principle 1.fix: Principle 1 is waste prevention. Principle 9 is catalysis.
catalysis is principle 1.action: Review the 12 principles. Catalysis and energy efficiency (6) are both relevant here.

green chemistry avoids all catalysts.error: Green chemistry PROMOTES the use of catalysts.
green chemistry avoids all catalysts.fix: Catalysts are preferred because they reduce energy needs and are not consumed.
green chemistry avoids all catalysts.action: Catalysts are reusable, unlike stoichiometric reagents that become waste.

catalysis only matters for organic react.error: Catalysis is important in all types of chemistry, including industrial inorganic processes.
catalysis only matters for organic react.fix: The Haber process (inorganic) uses iron catalyst. Green H2 production uses catalysts.
catalysis only matters for organic react.action: Think of any large-scale chemical process - most use catalysts.

catalysts are too expensive for green ch.error: Although catalysts may have upfront costs, they are more sustainable overall.
catalysts are too expensive for green ch.fix: Catalysts are not consumed, so can be used repeatedly. This reduces long-term costs and waste.
catalysts are too expensive for green ch.action: Compare: buy catalyst once vs buy stoichiometric reagent every batch.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how catalysis relates to sustainability.
persistent.action: Research how enzymes (biocatalysts) are being used in pharmaceutical manufacturing.

green_chemistry_energy_efficiency.name: Green Chemistry Principle: Energy Efficiency
green_chemistry_energy_efficiency.correct: Design for energy efficiency means minimising energy requirements by using ambient temperature and pressure where possible, reducing the environmental and economic impact of chemical processes.

energy efficiency is about using more en.error: Opposite. Energy efficiency is about using LESS energy.
energy efficiency is about using more en.fix: Lower temperatures and pressures require less energy input.
energy efficiency is about using more en.action: Less energy used = lower cost + lower environmental impact.

energy efficiency means faster reactions.error: Energy efficiency is about reducing energy consumption, not increasing speed.
energy efficiency means faster reactions.fix: A fast reaction at very high T uses more energy than a slower reaction at moderate T.
energy efficiency means faster reactions.action: Green chemistry may accept slower reactions if energy savings are significant.

this principle only applies to heating.error: Energy efficiency applies to all energy inputs including pressure, mixing, separation.
this principle only applies to heating.fix: High pressures also require energy (compressors). Separation processes use energy.
this principle only applies to heating.action: Consider total energy: heating + pressurising + separation + cooling.

energy efficiency is not a green chemist.error: Energy efficiency is explicitly principle 6 of the 12 green chemistry principles.
energy efficiency is not a green chemist.fix: Design for energy efficiency: Recognise energy requirements and minimise them.
energy efficiency is not a green chemist.action: Review the 12 principles proposed by Anastas and Warner in 1998.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how energy efficiency relates to sustainable chemistry.
persistent.action: Calculate energy costs for a reaction at different temperatures to see the economic impact.

haber_process_example.name: Haber Process as Example
haber_process_example.correct: The Haber process uses moderate temperature (400-500Â°C), high pressure (150-300 atm), and iron catalyst to balance rate and yield in ammonia production.

uses very high temperatures for maximum.error: High temperature decreases yield because the reaction is exothermic.
uses very high temperatures for maximum.fix: The Haber process uses moderate T (400-500Â°C) as a compromise, not maximum T.
uses very high temperatures for maximum.action: Higher T = faster but less NH3 at equilibrium. Moderate T balances both.

uses low pressure for safety.error: The Haber process actually uses very HIGH pressure (150-300 atm).
uses low pressure for safety.fix: High pressure favours the side with fewer gas molecules: 4 mol reactants â†’ 2 mol products.
uses low pressure for safety.action: High pressure increases yield AND rate (higher concentration). Worth the cost.

does not use a catalyst.error: The Haber process uses an iron catalyst.
does not use a catalyst.fix: Without catalyst, the rate at moderate temperatures would be far too slow.
does not use a catalyst.action: Iron catalyst enables reasonable rates at temperatures that give acceptable yields.

produces 100% yield.error: Equilibrium means yield is never 100% in a single pass.
produces 100% yield.fix: Actual yield per pass is about 15-20%. Unreacted gases are recycled.
produces 100% yield.action: Recycling unreacted N2 and H2 effectively increases overall conversion.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how the Haber process balances competing factors.
persistent.action: Create a table listing each condition (T, P, catalyst) and explaining why it was chosen.

biocatalysis.name: Biocatalysis
biocatalysis.correct: Biocatalysis uses enzymes (biological catalysts) which operate at mild conditions (low temperature, neutral pH, atmospheric pressure), aligning with green chemistry principles.

enzymes only work in living organisms.error: Enzymes can be extracted and used in industrial processes.
enzymes only work in living organisms.fix: Isolated enzymes are increasingly used in pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturing.
enzymes only work in living organisms.action: Research enzyme use in detergents, food processing, and drug synthesis.

biocatalysis requires high temperatures.error: Opposite. Enzymes typically work best at moderate temperatures (25-40Â°C).
biocatalysis requires high temperatures.fix: This is a key advantage: no expensive heating required.
biocatalysis requires high temperatures.action: Most enzymes denature above 60Â°C. They are designed for biological conditions.

enzymes are less efficient than metal ca.error: Enzymes are often MORE efficient and MORE selective than traditional catalysts.
enzymes are less efficient than metal ca.fix: Enzymes can have very high turnover numbers and produce fewer by-products.
enzymes are less efficient than metal ca.action: High selectivity means less waste and easier purification.

biocatalysis is not relevant to green ch.error: Biocatalysis is a major area of green chemistry research.
biocatalysis is not relevant to green ch.fix: Enzymes operate at mild conditions, are biodegradable, and highly selective.
biocatalysis is not relevant to green ch.action: Biocatalysis aligns with multiple green chemistry principles.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the advantages of biocatalysis.
persistent.action: Compare traditional vs enzymatic synthesis of a pharmaceutical compound.

removing_product.name: Removing Product to Increase Yield
removing_product.formula: Remove product â†’ equilibrium shifts right â†’ more product formed
removing_product.correct: Continuously removing product as it forms shifts equilibrium toward products, effectively increasing overall yield beyond single-pass equilibrium.

removing product decreases yield.error: Opposite. Removing product increases total yield over time.
removing product decreases yield.fix: Le Chatelier: removing product creates a stress that the system opposes by making more product.
removing product decreases yield.action: Think: if you keep taking NH3 away, the reaction keeps making more to replace it.

removing product speeds up the reaction.error: Removing product shifts equilibrium but does not directly affect rate.
removing product speeds up the reaction.fix: Rate depends on reactant concentrations. Removing product affects equilibrium position.
removing product speeds up the reaction.action: The forward rate may actually decrease as products are removed (less reverse reaction).

this only works for endothermic reaction.error: Removing product works for both exothermic and endothermic reactions.
this only works for endothermic reaction.fix: Le Chatelier's principle for concentration applies regardless of Î”H.
this only works for endothermic reaction.action: The principle is the same: removing a species shifts equilibrium to replace it.

products cannot be removed from equilibr.error: Many industrial processes are designed to continuously remove products.
products cannot be removed from equilibr.fix: Condensing NH3 in Haber process, removing H2O in esterification, etc.
products cannot be removed from equilibr.action: This is a key industrial strategy to drive reactions toward completion.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how Le Chatelier's principle applies to product removal.
persistent.action: Trace through the Haber process including the condensation step for NH3 removal.

rate_yield_conflict.title: Understanding the Rate-Yield Conflict
rate_yield_conflict.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of the conflict between rate and yield.

sentences.text: In industrial chemistry, there is often a conflict between achieving a high reaction {{d1}} and obtaining a high product {{d2}} at equilibrium.

d1.tooltip: Which factor describes how fast a reaction occurs?

d2.tooltip: Which factor describes how much product is formed?

sentences.text: Increasing temperature {{d3}} increases the rate of a chemical reaction, but for {{d4}} reactions, it shifts equilibrium toward reactants.

d3.tooltip: Does temperature always or only sometimes affect rate?

d4.tooltip: Which type of reaction produces heat as a product?

sentences.text: For an exothermic reaction, high temperatures increase rate but {{d5}} the equilibrium yield of products because the equilibrium shifts to the {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Does high T help or hurt product yield for exothermic reactions?

temperature_compromise.title: Finding the Optimal Temperature
temperature_compromise.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about compromise conditions in industrial processes.

sentences.text: Industrial processes use {{d1}} temperatures rather than very high or very low temperatures to balance rate and yield requirements.

d1.tooltip: What type of temperature represents a middle ground?

sentences.text: The Haber process for ammonia production operates at {{d2}} temperature (400-500Â°C) because the reaction is {{d3}} and very high temperatures would reduce yield.

d2.tooltip: Is 400-500Â°C considered moderate or extreme for industrial processes?

d3.tooltip: The Î”H for ammonia synthesis is negative, meaning it is...

sentences.text: At very low temperatures, even though yield would be {{d4}}, the reaction rate becomes too {{d5}} to be economically viable.

d4.tooltip: For exothermic reactions, low T favours products, so yield is...

d5.tooltip: What happens to rate at low temperatures?

sentences.text: A compromise is necessary because conditions favouring high {{d6}} often oppose conditions favouring high {{d7}}.

d7.tooltip: For exothermic reactions, low temperature increases which factor?

catalysis_principle.title: Green Chemistry Principle: Catalysis
catalysis_principle.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about the role of catalysts and green chemistry.

sentences.text: Catalysts increase the {{d1}} of a reaction by providing an alternative pathway with {{d2}} activation energy.

d1.tooltip: Do catalysts affect how fast or how much?

d2.tooltip: Do catalysts make it easier or harder to reach the transition state?

sentences.text: Importantly, catalysts do {{d3}} change the equilibrium position or the value of {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Can catalysts shift where equilibrium lies?

d4.tooltip: What symbol represents the equilibrium constant?

sentences.text: Catalysis is principle number {{d5}} of the 12 green chemistry principles proposed by Anastas and Warner.

d5.tooltip: Principle 1 is waste prevention, 6 is energy efficiency, 12 is accident prevention.

sentences.text: The green chemistry principle states that {{d6}} reagents are superior to stoichiometric reagents because they are not {{d7}} in the reaction.

d6.tooltip: Which type of reagent can be used repeatedly?

d7.tooltip: Catalysts are regenerated at the end of the reaction, meaning they are not...

energy_efficiency.title: Green Chemistry Principle: Energy Efficiency
energy_efficiency.instructions: Complete the dropdowns about designing for energy efficiency.

sentences.text: The green chemistry principle of designing for energy efficiency is principle number {{d1}} and focuses on {{d2}} energy requirements.

d1.tooltip: Which number principle addresses energy use?

d2.tooltip: Does green chemistry want more or less energy use?

sentences.text: Energy efficient processes favour reactions at {{d3}} temperature and {{d4}} pressure where possible.

d3.tooltip: What temperature requires no heating or cooling?

sentences.text: Using catalysts supports energy efficiency because they allow reactions to proceed at {{d5}} temperatures than would otherwise be required.

d5.tooltip: Catalysts make reactions faster, so you need... temperature.

sentences.text: Biocatalysis using {{d6}} is increasingly important because these biological catalysts operate at mild conditions around {{d7}}Â°C.

d6.tooltip: What biological molecules act as catalysts?

d7.tooltip: What is normal body temperature where most enzymes work best?

rate_yield_conflict.title: Applying Rate-Yield Conflict Understanding
rate_yield_conflict.instructions: Apply your understanding of rate-yield conflicts to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A chemical engineer notices that doubling the reactor temperature makes the reaction twice as fast, but equilibrium analysis shows product yield drops from 60% to 25%. This demonstrates the {{d1}} between rate and yield for {{d2}} reactions.

d1.tooltip: Rate went up but yield went down - what does this show?

d2.tooltip: High T decreasing yield indicates the forward reaction releases heat.

sentences.text: For the reaction 2SO2(g) + O2(g) â‡Œ 2SO3(g), Î”H = -198 kJ molâ»Â¹, increasing temperature will {{d3}} the rate but {{d4}} the concentration of SO3 at equilibrium.

d3.tooltip: What happens to rate when T increases?

d4.tooltip: For this exothermic reaction, high T shifts equilibrium...

sentences.text: The value of K for an exothermic reaction {{d5}} when temperature increases, while the rate of reaching equilibrium {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: K favours products. If equilibrium shifts left at high T, K must...

d6.tooltip: Equilibrium is reached faster or slower at high T?

temperature_compromise.title: Industrial Compromise Conditions
temperature_compromise.instructions: Apply your understanding of compromise conditions to industrial scenarios.

sentences.text: The Haber process uses an iron {{d1}} to achieve acceptable rates at the moderate temperature of 400-500Â°C, which gives an equilibrium yield of only {{d2}} per pass.

d1.tooltip: What speeds up the reaction without being consumed?

d2.tooltip: Is single-pass yield high or relatively low?

sentences.text: To increase overall conversion despite low single-pass yield, the Haber process {{d3}} unreacted nitrogen and hydrogen back through the reactor.

d3.tooltip: What is done with unreacted gases?

sentences.text: The ammonia produced is continuously {{d4}} by cooling, which shifts the equilibrium toward {{d5}} and increases overall yield.

d4.tooltip: NH3 has a higher boiling point so it can be condensed and...

d5.tooltip: Removing product causes the system to make more... what?

sentences.text: High pressure of 150-300 atm is used because it favours the side with {{d6}} gas molecules, which in this case is the {{d7}} side.

d6.tooltip: High pressure favours the side with smaller total moles of gas.

d7.tooltip: 4 moles of reactants â†’ 2 moles of products. Which has fewer?

catalysis_principle.title: Applying the Catalysis Principle
catalysis_principle.instructions: Apply your understanding of catalysis to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A pharmaceutical company reduced its synthesis from ten steps to three by using a more {{d1}} catalyst, significantly reducing {{d2}} generation.

d1.tooltip: What property allows fewer reaction steps?

d2.tooltip: Fewer steps means less unwanted material produced.

sentences.text: Unlike stoichiometric reagents that become waste after use, catalysts can be {{d3}} many times, making them more {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Catalysts are not consumed, so they can be...

d4.tooltip: Less waste and reusability contribute to...

sentences.text: Adding a catalyst to an equilibrium system will cause equilibrium to be reached {{d5}} but the final concentrations of products and reactants will be {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Catalysts speed up the approach to equilibrium.

d6.tooltip: Catalysts do not shift equilibrium position.

energy_efficiency.title: Applying Energy Efficiency Principles
energy_efficiency.instructions: Apply your understanding of energy efficiency to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A traditional industrial process operating at 800Â°C was redesigned using a new catalyst to run at 200Â°C. This represents a major improvement in {{d1}} efficiency.

d1.tooltip: Lower operating temperature means less heating required.

sentences.text: Enzymes are excellent biocatalysts because they typically operate at {{d2}} temperature, {{d3}} pH, and atmospheric pressure.

d2.tooltip: Enzymes evolved to work in living organisms at around 37Â°C.

d3.tooltip: Most biological systems operate near pH 7.

sentences.text: The pharmaceutical industry has shifted toward biocatalysis because enzymes produce {{d4}} by-products due to their high {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: Enzymes are very specific, reducing unwanted reactions.

d5.tooltip: What property describes an enzyme's ability to catalyse only specific reactions?

sentences.text: Using catalysts to enable reactions at lower temperatures directly addresses the conflict between rate and {{d6}} for exothermic reactions.

d6.tooltip: Lower T improves yield for exothermic reactions, and catalyst maintains rate.

rate_yield_conflict.title: Mastering Rate-Yield Concepts
rate_yield_conflict.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by addressing common misconceptions about rate and yield.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that catalysts increase yield. In reality, catalysts increase {{d1}} but do not change the {{d2}} position.

d2.tooltip: Catalysts speed up reaching equilibrium but do not shift where it lies.

sentences.text: Students often confuse rate and extent. Rate describes {{d3}} equilibrium is reached, while extent (yield) describes {{d4}} product is formed.

d3.tooltip: Rate is about speed, measured in mol Lâ»Â¹ sâ»Â¹.

d4.tooltip: Yield is about amount, measured in percentage or mass.

sentences.text: For the exothermic Haber reaction, increasing temperature shifts equilibrium {{d5}} but reaches that equilibrium {{d6}}, illustrating the rate-yield conflict.

d5.tooltip: High T favours the endothermic direction (reverse) for exothermic reactions.

d6.tooltip: Higher temperature always speeds up reactions.

temperature_compromise.title: Evaluating Compromise Strategies
temperature_compromise.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by evaluating different compromise strategies.

sentences.text: The Haber process accepts a low single-pass yield of 15-20% because the compromise conditions allow for {{d1}} production rates, and unreacted gases are {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: The goal is economic viability, not maximum yield.

sentences.text: Without the iron catalyst, the Haber process would need {{d3}} temperatures to achieve acceptable rates, which would {{d4}} the equilibrium yield.

d3.tooltip: Without catalyst, more thermal energy needed to overcome activation barrier.

d4.tooltip: Higher T = lower yield for exothermic reactions.

sentences.text: Continuously removing ammonia by {{d5}} effectively drives the reaction toward {{d6}}, compensating for the moderate temperature compromise.

d5.tooltip: NH3 has a higher boiling point than N2 and H2, so it can be liquefied.

d6.tooltip: Removing product shifts equilibrium right, making more product.

catalysis_principle.title: Evaluating Green Chemistry Catalysis
catalysis_principle.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by evaluating catalysis in green chemistry contexts.

sentences.text: The sertraline synthesis was improved from over 10 steps to just 3 by using a more {{d1}} catalyst, which reduced waste by {{d2}} orders of magnitude.

d1.tooltip: Selectivity means fewer unwanted side reactions.

d2.tooltip: Original: ~100 kg waste per kg product. Improved: ~1 kg waste per kg product.

sentences.text: Biocatalysis aligns with green chemistry because enzymes are {{d3}}, operate under {{d4}} conditions, and produce fewer by-products.

d3.tooltip: Enzymes are proteins that can be broken down naturally.

d4.tooltip: Low temperature, neutral pH, atmospheric pressure.

sentences.text: The principle of catalysis (principle {{d5}}) and designing for energy efficiency (principle {{d6}}) work together to address the rate-yield conflict sustainably.

d6.tooltip: Design for energy efficiency is principle 6.

energy_efficiency.title: Integrating Green Chemistry Principles
energy_efficiency.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by integrating energy efficiency concepts.

sentences.text: By using catalysts, reactions can occur at {{d1}} temperatures, which both {{d2}} energy costs and, for exothermic reactions, {{d3}} equilibrium yield.

d1.tooltip: Catalysts allow acceptable rates at reduced temperatures.

d2.tooltip: Lower operating temperature = less heating required.

d3.tooltip: Lower T for exothermic reactions favours products.

sentences.text: The 12 principles of green chemistry were proposed by {{d4}} and Warner in 1998 to reduce the use and generation of {{d5}} substances.

d4.tooltip: Paul Anastas is known as the father of green chemistry.

d5.tooltip: Green chemistry aims to reduce harmful chemicals.

sentences.text: Green chemistry resolves the rate-yield conflict by using {{d6}} to maintain rate while allowing {{d7}} operating temperatures that favour yield.

d6.tooltip: Catalysts increase rate without needing high temperatures.

d7.tooltip: For exothermic reactions, lower T improves yield.

rate_yield_conflict.title: The Rate-Yield Conflict
rate_yield_conflict.content: In industrial chemistry, there is often a fundamental conflict between achieving fast reaction rates and high product yields. This is especially pronounced for exothermic reactions, where the conditions that speed up the reaction (high temperature) actually reduce the amount of product formed at equilibrium.
keyPoints: Rate = how fast products form (kinetics)
Yield = how much product at equilibrium (thermodynamics)
For exothermic reactions: high T increases rate but decreases yield
A compromise must balance economic viability with product output

temperature_effect_rate.title: Temperature Effect on Reaction Rate
temperature_effect_rate.content: Temperature always increases reaction rate, regardless of whether the reaction is exothermic or endothermic. Higher temperature increases the kinetic energy of particles, leading to more frequent collisions and a greater proportion of collisions with energy exceeding the activation energy.
keyPoints: Higher T â†’ more kinetic energy â†’ more collisions
Higher T â†’ more particles exceed Ea
Rate increase applies to ALL reactions
This is a kinetic effect, separate from equilibrium effects

temperature_effect_equilibrium_exothermi.title: Temperature Effect on Exothermic Equilibrium
temperature_effect_equilibrium_exothermi.content: For exothermic reactions (Î”H < 0), heat can be considered as a product. By Le Chatelier's principle, adding heat (increasing temperature) shifts equilibrium toward reactants to absorb the added heat. This decreases the equilibrium yield of products and decreases the value of K.
keyPoints: Exothermic: A + B â†’ C + heat
Adding heat (â†‘T) shifts equilibrium left
K decreases as temperature increases for exothermic reactions
Temperature is the only factor that changes K

compromise_conditions.title: Industrial Compromise Conditions
compromise_conditions.content: Industrial processes must find a balance between rate and yield. Using moderate temperatures (neither too high nor too low) combined with catalysts allows for acceptable reaction rates without sacrificing too much yield.
keyPoints: Very high T: fast but low yield (for exothermic)
Very low T: high yield but impractically slow
Moderate T + catalyst: balanced rate and yield
Recycling and product removal further improve conversion

catalyst_role.title: Catalyst Role in Equilibrium Systems
catalyst_role.content: Catalysts increase the rate of both forward and reverse reactions equally by providing an alternative pathway with lower activation energy. They help the system reach equilibrium faster but do not change where equilibrium lies.
keyPoints: Catalysts â†‘ rate of BOTH forward and reverse reactions
Catalysts â†“ activation energy for both directions
Catalysts do NOT change K or equilibrium position
Same destination, faster journey

green_chemistry_catalysis.title: Green Chemistry Principle: Catalysis
green_chemistry_catalysis.content: Catalysis is principle 9 of the 12 green chemistry principles proposed by Anastas and Warner. It states that catalytic reagents are superior to stoichiometric reagents. Catalysts are not consumed, can be reused, reduce waste, and enable reactions under milder conditions.
keyPoints: Principle 9 of 12 green chemistry principles
Catalytic > stoichiometric reagents
Catalysts are not consumed and can be reused
Enables milder conditions, reducing energy and waste

green_chemistry_energy_efficiency.title: Green Chemistry Principle: Design for Energy Efficiency
green_chemistry_energy_efficiency.content: Design for energy efficiency is principle 6 of the 12 green chemistry principles. It emphasizes minimizing energy requirements by conducting reactions at ambient temperature and pressure where possible.
keyPoints: Principle 6 of 12 green chemistry principles
Minimize energy requirements
Prefer ambient temperature and pressure
Reduces environmental and economic impacts

haber_process_example.title: The Haber Process as a Case Study
haber_process_example.content: The Haber process for ammonia synthesis (N2 + 3H2 â‡Œ 2NH3, Î”H = -92 kJ molâ»Â¹) exemplifies the rate-yield compromise. It uses moderate temperature (400-500Â°C), high pressure (150-300 atm), and iron catalyst.
keyPoints: Moderate T (400-500Â°C): balance rate and yield
High P (150-300 atm): favours product side (4 mol â†’ 2 mol)
Iron catalyst: enables acceptable rate at moderate T
Recycle unreacted gases, condense and remove NH3

biocatalysis.title: Biocatalysis
biocatalysis.content: Biocatalysis uses enzymes (biological catalysts) in industrial processes. Enzymes operate at mild conditions (typically 25-40Â°C, neutral pH, atmospheric pressure), are highly selective, biodegradable, and can be produced sustainably.
keyPoints: Enzymes work at mild conditions (~37Â°C, pH 7, 1 atm)
High selectivity reduces by-products and waste
Biodegradable and can be produced from bacteria
Increasingly used in pharmaceutical manufacturing

removing_product.title: Removing Product to Increase Yield
removing_product.content: Continuously removing product as it forms shifts equilibrium toward products by Le Chatelier's principle. The system responds to the removal by making more product to restore equilibrium.
keyPoints: Removing product shifts equilibrium right
System makes more product to replace what was removed
Works for both exothermic and endothermic reactions
Examples: condensing NH3, removing H2O in esterification
